items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: In a Crowded City, Storage Rooms With Amenities
items.abstract: A new self-storage facility, with customer-friendly extras, has opened on Manhattan’s West Side, but analysts said the city remains underserved.

items.title: Cities Urge Public Pension Funds to Divest From Gun Makers
items.abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago urged the executives of two major banks to cease the financing of firearms companies. Other cities are making similar efforts.

items.title: Balthazar Korab, Architectural Photographer, Dies at 86
items.abstract: Mr. Korab was one of a handful of commercial photographers who introduced postwar architecture to Americans.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: How to Build Affordable Housing in New York City
items.abstract: Recent projects in which public housing was renovated by private developers could show a path forward.

items.title: New York City’s Pension System in Danger of ‘Operational Failure,’ Report Says
items.abstract: The bureau managing the city’s retirement funds has not kept up with the times and lacks basic tools to identify risk, according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.

items.title: Donald Trump Finds New City to Insult: Brussels
items.abstract: “It’s like living in a hellhole right now,” Donald J. Trump told the Fox Business Network anchor Maria Bartiromo.

items.title: New York City Council Members, at Hearing, Defend Raising Own Pay
items.abstract: Two days before they are expected to vote to increase their salaries by nearly a third, council members held the only public hearing on bills that would also enact significant reforms.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: They Married at City Hall (But Didn’t Toss the Bouquet)
items.abstract: Three couples share their stories after marrying on a December day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where the brides also rented their flowers.

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: N.Y. Today: The Mayor’s Vision for the City
items.abstract: Mayor de Blasio has already announced major policies, so what’s the teleprompter for? Also, “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” returns.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
items.abstract: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: Why a Blue City Is Feeling the Blues
items.abstract: New York is paying a price for Wall Street’s economic dominance.
